qas.question: What type of state is the Philippines?
What types of powers does the Philippines have?

answers.text: some powers devolved to Local Government Units (LGUs) under the terms of the Local Government Code

qas.question: What type of modifications been added to the Philippines Constitution?

answers.text: possible transition to a federal system as part of a shift to a parliamentary system.

qas.question: What did President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo establish?
What type of state isn't the Philippines?

plausible_answers.text: some powers devolved to Local Government Units (LGUs) under the terms of the Local Government Code

qas.question: What types of powers does the Philippines give up?

plausible_answers.text: possible transition to a federal system as part of a shift to a parliamentary system

qas.question: What type of modifications have been removed from the Philippines Constitution?

plausible_answers.text: possible transition to a federal system as part of a shift to a parliamentary system

qas.question: What type of songs have been added to the Philippines Constitution?
What did President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo desolve?

context: The Philippines is a <a0_0><b4_0>unitary state<b4_0/><a0_0/> with <a1_0><b5_0>some powers devolved to Local Government Units (LGUs) under the terms of the Local Government Code<b5_0/><a1_0/>. There is also one autonomous region, the Autonomous Region of Muslim Mindanao. Over the years various modifications have been proposed to the Constitution of the Philippines, including <a2_0><b6_0><b7_0>possible transition to a federal system as part of a shift to a parliamentary system<b7_0/><b6_0/>.<a2_0/> In 2004, Philippine President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo established <a3_0><b8_0>the Consultative Commission<b8_0/><a3_0/> which suggested such a Charter Change but no action was taken by the Philippine Congress to amend the 1987 Constitution.
